description: Check whether you'll have to pay to replace cladding or to fix other safety problems with your building.

hidden_search_terms: If you’re a leaseholder in England, check whether you’ll have to pay to replace cladding or to fix other safety problems with your building. If you have more than one property, answer for one property at a time. You’ll need to know the value of the property the last time it was sold before 14 February 2022. Check your lease if you’re not sure or search sold property prices .
Was your property built by a developer who's agreed to pay for building safety works?
Check with your freeholder or landlord (the person or organisation responsible for fixing problems with the building) or answer 'I do not know' if you're not sure.
Is your building at least 5 storeys or 11 metres tall?
The ground floor is storey 1. Do not count any underground floors, for example a basement or car park.
Is your building owned completely by some or all of the leaseholders?
Check your lease if you're not sure.
Do you own more than 3 residential properties in the UK?
Was the property your main home on 14 February 2022?
When did you buy your property?
In what year did you buy your property?
How much did you pay for your property?
You'll get a more accurate answer if you enter the exact value.
Is your property in Greater London?
Answer yes if your property is in a London borough, in the City of London or in the Inner or Middle Temple.
Do you own part of your property through a shared ownership scheme and pay rent on the other part?
What percentage of the property do you own?
Check your shared ownership lease if you’re not sure.
How much have you or previous owners already paid since 2017 for fixing safety problems in your building?
Include the cost of fixing any fault from the last 30 years that could have caused fire to spread or the building to collapse.
You do not have to pay to fix building safety problems, including replacing cladding

Your building’s developer has agreed to pay. You do not have to pay anything towards the cost of fixing a fault from the last 30 years if both of the following apply: it puts people’s safety at risk because fire could spread or the building could collapse it was caused by building work, including the building being built
Your building is not likely to need major safety work

Your building is very unlikely to need expensive work to make it safe. This is because there’s no evidence that the structure of buildings below 5 storeys or 11 metres creates safety risks. Check your lease to find out what costs you might have to pay. If you’re being asked to pay for major building safety work, contact under11mbuildings@levellingup.gov.uk . The Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities will investigate any expensive work to buildings under 5 storeys or 11 metres to find out why the building owner is doing this work.
You might have to contribute to fixing building safety problems, including replacing cladding
Check if you are eligible to apply for the Building Safety Fund for financial help towards fixing your building.
You might have to contribute to fixing building safety problems, including replacing cladding

Check your lease to find out what costs you might have to pay. You do not have to pay more than the share set out in your lease, even if other leaseholders in the building are protected from paying for building safety work. Your landlord (the person or organisation responsible for fixing problems with the building) must prove that they or other landlords in the building (including the freeholder) were not responsible for causing the problems. For example they might be responsible because they built the building. If they cannot prove this they will have to pay to fix the building safety problems themselves.
